title: Before 1 October 2017, will it be announced that the Large Hadron Collider has found evidence of "sparticles?"

0.003% chance. Because physics is a slow moving field for the past few hundred years and October isn't far enough away to expect any big discoveries.  I'm tempted to raise my prediction on account of the vague question which doesn't include who will announce it. Such that, for example, I could personally announce it and then get a hole in one prediction. Also the word "evidence" is pretty weak. However I believe the question is referring to "confirmation" when using the word "evidence" and the who in the announcement refers to any announcement with a valid source and the valid source is required to be accredited in the physics community with say a PHD to his credit. If those assumptions on the question are not true the scoring of my prediction is also not true as it is based on that interpretation.
They have found something else instead which is consuming their time and resources

We don't know if they exist. If they do, they explain some things like dark matter. We know that LHC has ramped up efforts to look for these particles in 2017. The last time they discovered something it took them 6 months for confirming the data before "announcing". Adding all that, and the tight deadline, i'll put < 1% odds.

So, Run 1 was generating data at 8 TeV while Run 2 is generating data at 13 TeV.  My understanding is that the higher energy output can generate much more data within the same period of operation time.  Calibration provides for search optimization by indicating certain areas of focus in the parameter space.  So maybe the question becomes, how quickly can we shift through the data?  The limitation should be computing power, right?  Or, is the limitation also a function of the operating energy that allows us to search parameter space that is inaccessible to the previous and possibly the current energy output?  Am I understanding this correctly? I'm dropping my overly-optimistic prediction to 2%.
This is probably not going to happen.   I

See Anneinak's link below for a report of the discovery of a new particle consistent with the Standard Model.   No reports of the discovery of particles that support the BSM though.  This type of baryon has been predicted by SM theory but detection has eluded researchers until now. "The results were based on the 13 TeV of data that was recorded during run 2 of the LHC, and confirmed by 8 TeV data from run 1."
http://www.ibtimes.com/double-charm-cerns-lhcb-experiment-discovers-new-type-baryon-2562486 Could we also look beyond the proton-proton collision experiments performed at LHC for other lines of evidence that support BSM?  For instance, can we look at the exploration aimed at deep space for evidence of dark matter and what might constitute dark matter?  
https://cds.cern.ch/record/2011082/files/arXiv:1504.05091.pdf
http://www.ibtimes.com/what-dark-matter-made-scientists-estimate-mass-prime-candidate-axions-2440949
http://www.ibtimes.com/cerns-cast-experiment-limits-dark-matter-possibilities-not-finding-solar-axions-2533242 According to the articles linked above, no evidence has been found of solar axions which are postulated to comprise dark matter.  If I understand correctly, the discovery of axions supports the Standard Model while if dark matter is not composed of axions then dark matter would consist of other particles such as Weakly Interacting Massive Particles or WIMPs.  The Standard Model does not predict the presence of WIMPs.  So while the discovery of whether the type of particles comprising dark matter are WIMPs, a discovery that does not directly have bearing on the existence of sparticles, it still tends to indirectly support the BSM and possibly some of its predictions. LHC and dark matter phenomenology of the NUHGM
https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Maria_Cabrera2/publication/259010176_LHC_and_dark_matter_phenomenology_of_the_NUGHM/links/547de2a70cf2cfe203c2250d.pdf?disableCoverPage=true&inViewer=true&origin=publication_detail&pdfJsDownload=true
"We identify the most probable regions in the NUHGM parameter space...." So, large amounts of information are currently being generated by the operation of the LDC at a higher Tev and researchers are calibrating where to focus their search based on statistical modeling.  The prospect for particles consistent with NUHGM, a supersymmetry scenario, to be detected (not certain if NUHGM fits within an extension of the SM or whether is is BSM) increases.  Again, not direct evidence but may be evidence nevertheless that SUSY researchers may be vindicated though uncertain when.

Physicists have discovered a particle that is doubly charming.
........
An experiment at CERN, within the behemoth Large Hadron Collider, counted more 300 Xi-cc++ baryons, each consisting of two heavy charm quarks and one up quark. The discovery fits with the Standard Model, the prevailing understanding of how the smallest bits of the universe behave, and does not seem to point to new physics. “The existence of these particles has been predicted by the Standard Model,” said Patrick Spradlin, a physicist at the University of Glasgow who led the research. “Their properties have also been predicted.”
Retrieved from: https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/06/science/cern-quarks-charm-baryon.html

@astrophile here's something on false positives and negatives: 
 Once upon a time, we had faster than light neutrinos: 
Speaking at the time, Professor Ereditato added "words of caution" because of the "potentially great impact on physics" of the result. 
"We tried to find all possible explanations for this," he said. 
"We wanted to find a mistake - trivial mistakes, more complicated mistakes, or nasty effects - and we didn't. 
"When you don't find anything, then you say 'well, now I'm forced to go out and ask the community to scrutinise this'." 
Despite the call for caution, the results caused controversy within the world of physics. 
If the findings had been confirmed, they would have disproved Albert Einstein's 1905 Special Theory of Relativity. 
Earlier this month, a test run by a different group at the same Italian laboratory recorded neutrinos travelling at precisely light speed. 
Sandro Centro, co-spokesman for the Icarus collaboration, said that he was not surprised by the result. 
http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-17560379
xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx “I SEE a train wreck looming,” warned Daniel Kahneman, an eminent psychologist, in an open letter last year. The premonition concerned research on a phenomenon known as “priming”.
..........
The pitfalls Dr Stodden points to get deeper as research increasingly involves sifting through untold quantities of data. Take subatomic physics, where data are churned out by the petabyte. It uses notoriously exacting methodological standards, setting an acceptable false-positive rate of one in 3.5m (known as the five-sigma standard). But maximising a single figure of merit, such as statistical significance, is never enough: witness the “pentaquark” saga. Quarks are normally seen only two or three at a time, but in the mid-2000s various labs found evidence of bizarre five-quark composites. The analyses met the five-sigma test. But the data were not “blinded” properly; the analysts knew a lot about where the numbers were coming from. When an experiment is not blinded, the chances that the experimenters will see what they “should” see rise. This is why people analysing clinical-trials data should be blinded to whether data come from the “study group” or the control group. When looked for with proper blinding, the previously ubiquitous pentaquarks disappeared. Other data-heavy disciplines face similar challenges. Models which can be “tuned” in many different ways give researchers more scope to perceive a pattern where none exists. According to some estimates, three-quarters of published scientific papers in the field of machine learning are bunk because of this “overfitting”, says Sandy Pentland, a computer scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
....
The negative results are much more trustworthy; for the case where the power is 0.8 there are 875 negative results of which only 20 are false, giving an accuracy of over 97%. But researchers and the journals in which they publish are not very interested in negative results. They prefer to accentuate the positive, and thus the error-prone. Negative results account for just 10-30% of published scientific literature, depending on the discipline. This bias may be growing. A study of 4,600 papers from across the sciences conducted by Daniele Fanelli of the University of Edinburgh found that the proportion of negative results dropped from 30% to 14% between 1990 and 2007. Lesley Yellowlees, 
president of Britain’s Royal Society of Chemistry, has published more than 100 papers. She remembers only one that reported a negative result. Statisticians have ways to deal with such problems. But most scientists are not statisticians. Victoria Stodden, a statistician at Columbia, speaks for many in her trade when she says that scientists’ grasp of statistics has not kept pace with the development of complex mathematical techniques for crunching data. Some scientists use inappropriate techniques because those are the ones they feel comfortable with; others latch on to new ones without understanding their  subtleties. Some just rely on the methods built into their software, even if they don’t understand them.
Retrieved from: http://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21588057-scientists-think-science-self-correcting-alarming-degree-it-not-trouble The full article covers a lot more ground. If you do the Master Classes in the training section you'll see Danny Kahneman on the panel. @Wildwood2000 @Anneinak
Only indirect evidence for supersymmetry has been posited and it seems that multiple theoretical constructs are more easily available than testable verifications in grand physics recently.

The NYTimes published an interesting artcicle on CERN and the state of physics as a discipline and the direction the supersymmetry research program.  While some leading researchers are optimistic for the long term potential of this research program and it's central question, most international researchers at CERN indicate the discipline in a "state of confusion," (not from ignorance of central questions of the discipline) but see it as a potential for paradigmatic changes over time.  There is no agreement (scientific discovery cannot be 'forced' onto the empirical world, but emply the use of scientific methods to engage with process of discovery of phenomena not currently or previously known) among researchers regarding fundamental discovery of the primitives of the discipline;  whether and how, or even if,   the existence of sparticles will be empirically validated in their research.  The discipline of physics and the field of supersymmetry appears to on the cusp of significant and interesting discoveries that bound to change the fundamental foundations of the discipline.  However, only time will tell!

Even if they find something today, I suspect that they will be very careful before they make a formal announcement. Time is running out.

The quantum world is a weird world. Maybe our concept of time is going to change? 
At this point, quantum mechanics and relativity collide. One consequence of Einstein’s theories is that energy and mass are equivalent. This means energy, like mass, has a gravitational pull. A second consequence is that gravity changes the flow of time. Such gravitational time dilation is a well-established phenomenon. Atomic clocks kept at different altitudes on Earth, for example, get out of sync with one another because they are subjected to different gravitational forces.
..........
According to Dr Brukner, the clock thought experiment shows that the metric field is yet another phenomenon which is subject to Heisenberg’s principle, and therefore to superpositional effects. As a consequence, it is no longer only location in space that becomes uncertain, but also location in time. Often, therefore, it would no longer be possible to say which of two events came first. http://www.economist.com/news/science-and-technology/21723095-does-one-thing-lead-another-time-may-be-fuzzy-if-so-idea-causality The good new is that they think there's an experiment to test the hypothesis.  Why is it that you remember the past and not the future?
Scientists are terrible at keeping (non-classified) secrets. If there was a hint on this time-frame we would know by now. Data are being collected, but much  analysis is still needed.
If they emulate Good Judgment Open and crowdsource potential solutions to the issues that they are encountering, I believe that the likelihood will increase. ;-)
If they can't find it by now, they need something else to find it.

I'll drop two percentage points but keep the forecast above zero.  Do we know the specifics of the teams that are working on the search for sparticles, especially the latest work which might be inferred by looking at abstracts or presentations?  Would something like this leak out to the mainstream science media or would it tend to be buried in specialized science journals, etc.? "Stop co-annihilation turns out to be one of the most promising mechanisms for achieving an appropriate relic density of dark matter in all
three models, whilst avoiding all other constraints. We find high-likelihood regions of parameter space featuring light stops and charginos, making them potentially detectable in the near future at the LHC."
Global fits of GUT-scale SUSY models with GAMBIT:  https://arxiv.org/pdf/1705.07935.pdf Hmm...potentially detectable in the near future.  This task is almost like trying to decipher the pronouncements of the FOMC on matters of interest rate increases. It sounds to me like it's an issue of where to look in parameter space and not so much a function of detector sensitivity (instrument detection limit) although one would want high enough resolution to determine distinguishing characteristics at a high enough level of certainty.  The analogy to instrument detection limit is being able to distinguish a ship on the far horizon (background) but not necessarily being able to distinguish the type of ship or other characteristics.  A higher resolution allows one to determine certain characteristics such as the flag of origin, for example.   Are there other lines of evidence that would point to the existence of sparticles or rather support new physics (physics beyond the Standard Model)? "The measurements discussed were obtained using the entire data sample of the first period of exploitation of the Large Hadron Collider (Run 1). If the new measurements indeed point to physics beyond the Standard Model, the larger data sample collected in Run 2 will be sufficient to confirm these effects."

LHCb finds new hints of possible Standard Model deviations:  https://home.cern/about/updates/2017/04/lhcb-finds-new-hints-possible-standard-model-deviations "These results, published today in Nature Physics, will soon be updated with the larger data set collected so far during the second run of the LHC. If this earlier evidence for CP violation is seen again with greater significance in the larger sample, the result will be an important milestone in the study of CP violation." New source of asymmetry between matter and antimatter:  https://home.cern/about/updates/2017/01/new-source-asymmetry-between-matter-and-antimatter
All previous estimates of super symmetry have failed, advocates keep modifying their predictions unsuccessfully.

Page 25
Probability given the best known existing models is zero for the LHC being able to detect the sparticle. The likely mass of the sparticle, if and only if it exists in the first place, is far too high. Current constraints from the LHC push superpartner masses towards the multi-TeV regime, even if one does not demand that the lightest neutralino is the only DM species.  Global fits of GUT-scale SUSY models with GAMBIT
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1705.07935.pdf In addition, even if the sparticle had been found today, it would take easily over a year to collect enough evidence to prove it even at just 5 Sigma evidence level. If 9 Sigma is demanded, and it might be for such a controversial result, it could take over a decade!!!

The sparticle has been elusive so far. Its existence is theorized, yet no evidence has been found to support this theory. The chance scientist will positively find it is rather slim, which leaves the chance that they'll find something "statistically relevant" according to Fishers definition (i.e. 5% or more). 
Maybe they've learned from the message they found faster than light particles, which eventually also showed to be untrue.

Bumping forecast up to 7%.  Why?   An enormous amount of data was collected in 2016 when the experiments were performed at an energy of 8.16 TeV.  Can't say I understand the significance of the energy other than to say that it's related to luminosity.  The article states that luminosity is a measure of a collider's efficiency and is proportional to the number of collisions.   This increase in energy will also allow the beams to be more focused.  The overall operational goal is to improve optimization and to reduce uncertainty.  I would guess that besides the experimental data generated and captured by the LHC experiments that a parallel track will generate information for sensitivity analysis of existing predictive models.  Experimental data from the LHC can be provided as input for calibration of these predictive models. The LHC has been currently upgraded to 13 TeV.  So basically, with each improvement in energy output, the amount of data collected increases for a proportional amount of time of operation.  During this 2nd run, the energy output was set initially at 13 TeV with provision to increase to 14 TeV later in the run.
https://home.cern/about/updates/2016/12/2016-exceptional-year-lhc
https://home.cern/about/engineering/restarting-lhc-why-13-tev
https://run2-13tev.web.cern.ch/background/lhc-season-2-new-frontiers-physics
http://www.ibtimes.com/cern-lhc-update-large-hadron-collider-starts-2017-operations-earnest-2542974 Measurements from Data Run 1 found evidence of deviation from the Standard Model.  That is suggestive of a bridge between the Standard Model and the extended version of the Standard Model.  Presumably, the data set collected during the current run will be sufficient to confirm this interpretation of the data from Run 1.
https://home.cern/about/updates/2017/04/lhcb-finds-new-hints-possible-standard-model-deviations One particular finding that I find most intriguing and which may arise out of the Run 2 dataset is the existence of extra dimensions.  "Theories that require extra dimensions predict that, just as atoms have a low-energy state and excited high-energy states, there would be heavier versions of standard particles in other dimensions.  Such heavy particles could be revealed at the high energies the LHC will reach in Run 2."
https://run2-13tev.web.cern.ch/background/lhc-season-2-new-frontiers-physics The successive improvements are not limited to particular LHC hardware such as the detectors.  The improvements include computing power.  This graph shows the evolution of computing power over time, not specifically in relation to the LHC experiments but rather the general trend for all application that require very high levels of processing power. http://www.mocom2020.com/data/2009/05/computer-power-future.gif
http://www.mocom2020.com/2009/05/evolution-of-computer-capacity-and-costs/ Also look at this: https://gizmodo.com/the-trillion-fold-increase-in-computing-power-visualiz-1706676799 The Singularity is Near Increase in computing power: https://www.hpcwire.com/2016/11/04/intel-cern-support-lhc-experiments/
In addition to increasing power output, upgrade in detector (~resolution): http://www.smithsonianmag.com/smart-news/large-hadron-collider-has-open-heart-surgery-180962369/

I believe that even if they find some sort of bump that would point towards such a particle, it would take longer than that to confirm, because the low-hanging fruit in this search are already gone. So I am counting on the interpretation of "evidence" as a five sigma measurement, not some tentative result.
I think we are too far away from such a breakthrough.
I did not inform myself about specifics. But I consider it very unlikely, as 1) theory might be completely or partially wrong, 2) detector might not be good enough, 3) time factor.
Dropping as the more I read about this the bigger the challenge seems to be

They need very hight energy levels to be able to find these massive particles. The Large Hadron Collider has gone through a long period of maintenance and improvement and they expect to have "stable beams" at the end of this month (May, 2017). This means they only have 4 months to do the experiments, the analysis and the interpretation. I agree with @Anneinak that they will be very cautious before they announce such a big event. The last note from the ATLAS research team (https://atlas.cern/updates/physics-briefing/atlas-releases-new-results-search-weakly-interacting-supersymmetric) is that they did not find a "significant deviation" from what they expected. This does not mean that there are no sparticles, but that they have to be very, very heavy. I assume that this means it will be very difficult to find them.

Current research into theories of supersymmetry are suggesting that these "sparticles" either don't exist or are much heavier than originally anticipated.  It doesn't seem very likely that they will be found in the next few months.
I would be happy to be wrong on this one
Very very very unlikely, Just based on the fact that previous experiment involving large hadron collider usually involves mechanical issues, theoritical issues, sampling issues.

https://phys.org/news/2017-05-atlas-results-weakly-interacting-supersymmetric-particles.html "ATLAS physicists presented one of the first Run 2 searches for weakly-interacting sparticles at the LHCP 2017 conference... The analysis selected collision events containing two or three electrons and muons and large missing transverse momentum. The figure shows the measured distribution (data points) of missing transverse momentum in events with three leptons, compared to that expected from the Standard Model (coloured histogram). No significant deviation from the expectation was observed." Unlikely that there will be a result in 6 months with the time required for data acquisition, analysis, verification, and review.

Because of the importance & significance of the discovery of sparticles--because finding evidence of them will conclusively prove the supersymetry theory (as opposed to "String Theory" and "The Theory of everything")--there will be an excess of caution involved in the announcement if evidence is found. However, "Found evidence of" is not as high a standard as "found a sparticle". In wikipedia, I read that CERN has been down for 17 weeks for extensive repairs & upgrades and has just gotten fired back up about 3 weeks ago; I wonder if such an extended period of "down time" was considered when statements were made that evidence of sparticles would be found this year.   I'm wondering how long data analysis takes.  I'm guessing that it is more than 5 months (May 1-Oct 1). My thanks to all the other forecasters here, especially ErikFritzsche @ http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/507057, who have shared the fruits of their research.  As other forecasters have said, GJO posts are a great source of information.

How often can they experiment on that in the time till questions closes?
- unknown, but there is a series of experiments underway
- Note that it can be concluded from the timeline of operations as published here (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_Hadron_Collider#Timeline_of_operations) that there is some chance that the LHC has problems with its operation so that it needs time to fix it. How long will it take from the experiment to the interpretation of the data, so that it can be stated that there is a (positive) finding?
- I should add that I have no clue about what the particles, bosoms, sparticles are; I have no clue of the standard models, be they symmetric or non-symmetric, either. However, I tried to detect in the behaviour of LHC scientists - first - how contested their work is within the community and - second - how cautious they are with their findings and claims…
- I read the Wikipedia article on some findings of the first run (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_Hadron_Collider#First_run_.28data_taken_2009.E2.80.932013.29); I got the impression that scientists try to work on a theory that is highly contested and controversial: so they seem to be cautious with announcements of 
spectacular findings:
○ The Higgs bosom was - likely - detected in July 2012; however, since the discovery of the Higgs bosom has huge implications on the theory, scientists were very cautious on their claims.
○ Concerning the B meson data in August 2013 seemed difficult to interpret, so that an announcement of a new particle was not possible.
○ In November 2019 there seemed to be a valid discovery.
○ Some particle detection seemed to be very demanding and take time from June 2015 to June 2016.
○ December 2015 there were some preliminary results on Higgs physics.
○ Note, that most of these findings are within the - less disputed - non-symmetric standard model of the universe; some, however, were also discussed within the framework of symmetric standard model.  How likely is it that the theory is right?
- No evidence found, so far. No falsification, either. Could be right, could be wrong. Obviously, the scientific community is not very sure about the theories validity anymore, making it not likely that a positive finding will be communicated offensively. How long will it take from a positive finding to an announcement?
- Given the fact that supersymmetry theory seems to be empirically invalid to date, it seems very risky for LHC as an institution to announce a false positive: so it is plausible that they will carefully scrutinize their possible positive findings, will discuss them with peers, will try to reproduce the empirical result - and this will take time, probably very much time - making it less likely that we will have a positive announcement before 1 October this year.
- Therefore, I would conclude that Goeffrey Carr from the Economist (see article referred to in the question's explanatory section) is overconfident with regard to the speed with which in 2017 LHC can empirically test the supersymmetric hypotheses. It seems (much) more likely that at the end of 2017 we won't be better informed of the theories validity. How likely is it that the theory can be confirmed with the current run of LHC - given that it is right?
- unknown…
- Given the fact, that they tried to refine and adjust the LHC in several rounds and runs, it could well be possible that it is the wrong experiment to test the supersymmetric theory. At least it should be stated that it is disputable among scientific community how well suited the experiments of LHC are and whether the quality of the generated data is sufficient to infer what they wish to infer. All in all: experiments, theory, data: all is disputed… a positive announcement seems highly unlikely bevor 1 October this year, even if there would be a fitting pattern of supersymmetry theory in the data - since the announcement of a false positive result is likely to do a lot of harm to LHC. I think, however, the current consensus (2 percent) is a little bit underrating the event. I think it is very unlikely, however: starting with 5 per cent… ?  (BTW: Some commentators laughed at the theory and its funny terms. However, the history of science is full of theories that were correct but where completely mocked, e.g. Alfred Wegener was close to suicide since the world laughed at his continental drift theory, Max Planck and other quantum physicist earned a lot of criticism for their probability based model of the micro foundations of our universe, think of ancient ideas like democracy or the rather modern idea that humans could have rights that belong to them like a part of their body… many laughed at such concepts, but - eventually - they today shape our thinking to a large extent: and it seems unimaginable how someone could be mobbed and mocked just because he believed that it is a plausible scientific hypothesis that Africa and South America were once a single continent…) Last but not least I see some potential for a clarification of the question:
I am wondering a bit about the word "announcement" in the question since I do not really have an idea of what a positive announcement would look like. As I got it, LHC announcements on particles where so cautiously formulated that they hardly announced that they have discovered something with strong confidence… So, I think, there is clarification needed on what a positive announcement will be.

It is speculated that the discovery of such particles would bring about a "paradigm shift" in the field, meaning that this would be a MAJOR finding. But major findings aren't easy to come by and as the shift to this new (speculated) paradigm currently has zero evidence aside from the current paradigm's limitations, this signals the field still has awhile to go.
Not an expert but a lot of what I've read seems to indicate that, apart from no evidence, even the theoretical basis for its existence is very thin.

I hate to be cynical, and I admit to having only a passing interest in particle physics, but here goes. What I've read suggests that even if hints of sparticles are turning up in results, we are still a long way off from a confirmed discovery that is definitely not background noise and statistical fluctuations. On a side note, I have trouble taking seriously anything called a slepton or chargino. That's not related to anything, just a desire for less silly sounding names.

I'll start out below the consensus based on the article posted by @Frommelt where it's stated:  "Updated results could be ready in about half a year, he says, and should allow for a more definitive conclusion."  So, is LHCb spokesperson Guy Wilkinson speaking of 'sparticles' (superpartners) or about other particles? Of course, it's really shaky basing a prediction on a general science news article since the content tends to be about attention-getting and not necessarily a good source for the finer nuances of cutting edge research.  I suppose part of the question is whether an anomaly extracted from the data is an artifact of measurement or of statistical analysis or whether it is actually real.   I'd also suppose that before an official announcement is provided by CERN a great deal of verification will have been performed and vetted. Now, what if we find out the answer is "42"?
As one prominent physicist (and a sceptic of the theory) put it, supersymmetry is "not even wrong". That may change this year for at least some flavors of Susy.
Agree with Anneinak it's a nice question with something a bit different to learn about
I'm looking forward to learning a lot about this.
It's a long-shot. Yes it could happen, but most likely it will take more time and analysis before a conclusion can be made.
I think it comes down to how many attempts they can make then reset for the next shot. Even a test that fails yields clue to the next step in the search.

Supersymmetry has not been exactly acing its exams of late.  It's either more complicated than expected, more difficult to demonstrate than expected, or more imaginary than expected.   These are interesting, by which I mean terrifying, times for That Sort Of Physicist.
